time_and_mortality.explanation: Some wounds and griefs are lessened by the natural passage of time when intellectual cognitive restructuring falls short.

time_and_mortality.quote: While we wait for life, life passes.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: If you are always preparing to live, you will never actually start living. Engage in the present.

time_and_mortality.quote: You act like mortals in all that you fear, and like immortals in all that you desire.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: We anxiously fear things as if our time is short, yet we postpone our goals and values as if we have endless time.

time_and_mortality.quote: Let us prepare our minds as if we’d come to the very end of life. Let us postpone nothing.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Live with a sense of urgency, embracing your duties and joys now, not later.

time_and_mortality.quote: The part of life we really live is small. For all the rest of existence is not life, but merely time.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: True 'living' happens in moments of conscious, value-driven action; the rest is just the passing of time.

time_and_mortality.quote: Your days are numbered. Use them to throw open the windows of your soul to the sun.
time_and_mortality.author: Marcus Aurelius
time_and_mortality.explanation: Recognize the brevity of life and use your limited time to seek wisdom, truth, and inner light.

time_and_mortality.quote: While the fates permit, live happily; life speeds on with hurried step...
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Embrace the present joyfully and virtuously, because time is fleeting and waits for no one.

time_and_mortality.quote: No one can have a peaceful life who thinks too much about lengthening it.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Obsessing over extending your lifespan creates anxiety that ruins the quality of the life you have.

time_and_mortality.quote: Think of yourself as dead. You have lived your life. Now, take what's left and live it properly.
time_and_mortality.author: Marcus Aurelius
time_and_mortality.explanation: This mental exercise frees you from past mistakes and future anxieties, allowing you to focus on living virtuously now.

time_and_mortality.quote: The blaze of a reputation cannot be sustained by the ashes of the dead.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Your legacy is in the virtue of your life, not in the fame that may or may not follow your death.

time_and_mortality.quote: The problem with many people is they think they have time.
time_and_mortality.author: Carlos Castaneda
time_and_mortality.explanation: This anthropological insight mirrors the Stoic warning against acting as if your time is infinite. The illusion of endless time leads to procrastination.

time_and_mortality.quote: It is not that we are given a short life but we make it short.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Life feels short when we waste it on non-essentials. A life lived with purpose and virtue feels full, regardless of its length.

time_and_mortality.quote: The Present is the only thing a man can be deprived of.
time_and_mortality.author: Marcus Aurelius
time_and_mortality.explanation: You cannot lose the past (it's gone) or the future (it's not here). Your only possession is this present moment. Use it well.

time_and_mortality.quote: The time will come when you will be nowhere and nobody.
time_and_mortality.author: Marcus Aurelius
time_and_mortality.explanation: Reflect on your own impermanence not to be morbid, but to appreciate the present and act with purpose.

time_and_mortality.quote: Let each thing you would do, say, or intend, be like that of a dying person.
time_and_mortality.author: Marcus Aurelius
time_and_mortality.explanation: The thought of your imminent end brings clarity and moral seriousness to your present actions.

time_and_mortality.quote: We are always complaining that our days are few, and acting as though there would be no end of them.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Our actions contradict our awareness of mortality. Live as if you understand that your time is finite.

time_and_mortality.quote: Soon you will have forgotten all things: and soon all things will have forgotten you.
time_and_mortality.author: Marcus Aurelius
time_and_mortality.explanation: This is not a cause for despair, but for liberation. It frees you to act virtuously for its own sake, not for lasting fame.

time_and_mortality.quote: The common cognitive distortion is to believe that since an event is catastrophic, it is also highly probable.
time_and_mortality.author: David D. Burns
time_and_mortality.explanation: A leading CBT psychologist points out how we overestimate the likelihood of our fears, urging us to assess probabilities realistically.

time_and_mortality.quote: The fear of death follows from the fear of life.
time_and_mortality.author: Mark Twain
time_and_mortality.explanation: A person who is afraid of living fully and taking risks is the one who is most afraid of life ending.

time_and_mortality.quote: That which has existed is now, and that which is to be has already been.
time_and_mortality.author: Ecclesiastes
time_and_mortality.explanation: Recognize the cyclical nature of human experience. This perspective provides stability and peace.

time_and_mortality.quote: This is our big mistake: to think we look forward to death. Most of death is already gone. Whatever time has passed is owned by death.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Don't see death as a future event. It is a process that is happening now. Every moment that passes belongs to it. Live accordingly.

time_and_mortality.quote: A man does not die because he is sick, but because he is alive.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Death is not an accident or a failure; it is the natural and inevitable consequence of being born.

time_and_mortality.quote: It's not about avoiding death, but about living a life that's worth dying for.
time_and_mortality.author: Ryan Holiday
time_and_mortality.explanation: A modern Stoic take: focus on the quality and purpose of your actions, making your life meaningful regardless of its length.

time_and_mortality.quote: Perfection of character is this: to live each day as if it were your last, without frenzy, without apathy, without pretense.
time_and_mortality.author: Marcus Aurelius
time_and_mortality.explanation: The awareness of mortality should lead to a calm, engaged, and authentic way of living in the present.

time_and_mortality.quote: The longest portion of our life is the one we live for others.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Much of our time is spent on obligations and duties. Ensure the small portion you have for yourself is lived with wisdom.

time_and_mortality.quote: Of all the things which wisdom provides to make life entirely happy, much the greatest is the possession of friendship.
time_and_mortality.author: Epicurus
time_and_mortality.explanation: While Stoics valued self-sufficiency, they, like other ancient philosophers, recognized the profound importance of virtuous relationships.

time_and_mortality.quote: Every hour of every day is a test.
time_and_mortality.author: Marcus Aurelius
time_and_mortality.explanation: Each moment presents an opportunity to practice virtue, patience, and reason. Your life is a continuous examination of your character.

time_and_mortality.quote: You can't change the past, but you can ruin the present by worrying about the future.
time_and_mortality.author: Albert Ellis
time_and_mortality.explanation: A succinct psychological truth: focus your energy on the present moment, as it's the only one you can influence.

time_and_mortality.quote: Life, if well lived, is long enough.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: A life filled with virtuous action and purpose feels complete, regardless of its length in years.

time_and_mortality.quote: Alexander the Great and his mule driver both died and the same thing happened to both.
time_and_mortality.author: Marcus Aurelius
time_and_mortality.explanation: Death is the great equalizer. Status, wealth, and power are irrelevant in the end. Only your character has lasting worth.

time_and_mortality.quote: You could leave life right now. Let that determine what you do and say and think.
time_and_mortality.author: Marcus Aurelius
time_and_mortality.explanation: This is the ultimate filter for your actions. Let the reality of your mortality guide you to what is truly important.

time_and_mortality.quote: Men do not care how nobly they live, but only how long, although it is within the reach of every man to live nobly, but within no man's power to live long.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: We obsess over what we cannot control (length of life) and neglect what we can (quality of life).

time_and_mortality.quote: It is not death that is terrible, but the terrified death.
time_and_mortality.author: Epictetus
time_and_mortality.explanation: The event of dying is natural and neutral. The suffering comes from the fear and anxiety we attach to it.

time_and_mortality.quote: He who has made a fair compact with poverty is rich.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: By mentally preparing for and accepting the possibility of having little, you free yourself from the fear of it and find a different kind of wealth.

time_and_mortality.quote: No man can have a peaceful life who thinks too much about lengthening it.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Constant anxiety about extending your life prevents you from living the life you currently have with peace and virtue.

time_and_mortality.quote: Cease to hope and you will cease to fear.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Fear and hope are two sides of the same coin: attachment to a future you don't control. By giving up obsessive hope for a specific outcome, you also free yourself from the fear of not getting it.

time_and_mortality.quote: The whole future lies in uncertainty: live immediately.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Don't postpone living while waiting for a certain future. The only time you can truly live is now.

time_and_mortality.quote: What is the point of fearing a thing which is inevitable?
time_and_mortality.author: Epictetus
time_and_mortality.explanation: Wasting mental energy fearing death is irrational, as it is a natural and unavoidable part of life.

time_and_mortality.quote: The most grievous of all losses is the loss of time.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Unlike money or property, lost time can never be recovered. It is your most precious and non-renewable resource.

time_and_mortality.quote: We all have the same end; the only difference is the road we take.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: Since death is the common destination for all, the meaning of life is found in the virtuous manner in which you travel your unique path.

time_and_mortality.quote: Every man's life is a journey to death.
time_and_mortality.author: Seneca
time_and_mortality.explanation: This perspective isn't meant to be morbid, but to encourage a focused and purposeful life, knowing the destination is fixed.

time_and_mortality.quote: There is no saint without a past, no sinner without a future.
time_and_mortality.author: Augustine of Hippo
time_and_mortality.explanation: A theological idea with deep psychological truth: everyone has the capacity for change. Your past actions do not define your future potential for virtue.

time_and_mortality.quote: He who is not prepared today will be less so tomorrow.
time_and_mortality.author: Ovid
time_and_mortality.explanation: The time to cultivate the virtues needed for life's challenges is always now. Procrastination only weakens your resolve.

time_and_mortality.quote: The wise man is a teacher of the art of living.
time_and_mortality.author: Zeno of Citium
time_and_mortality.explanation: The ultimate purpose of wisdom is not private contemplation, but the practical application and teaching of how to live a virtuous life.

relationships_and_society.quote: The best revenge is to be unlike him who performed the injury.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: Responding to wrongdoing with virtue is the highest and most effective form of 'revenge', preserving your own character.

relationships_and_society.quote: The key is to keep company only with people who uplift you, whose presence calls forth your best.
relationships_and_society.author: Epictetus
relationships_and_society.explanation: Choose your companions wisely, as they have a significant influence on your character and behavior through social modeling.

relationships_and_society.quote: Attach yourself to what is spiritually superior, regardless of what other people think or do.
relationships_and_society.author: Epictetus
relationships_and_society.explanation: Commit to your principles and virtuous role models, even if it means going against social pressure.

relationships_and_society.quote: I have often wondered how it is that every man loves himself more than all the rest of men, but yet sets less value on his own opinion of himself than on the opinion of others.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: A paradox of human psychology: we are self-centered, yet we often value social approval over our own rational judgment.

relationships_and_society.quote: Be tolerant with others and strict with yourself.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: Hold yourself to a high standard of virtue while showing patience and understanding for the faults of others.

relationships_and_society.quote: Associate with people who are likely to improve you.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: Your character is influenced by the people you spend the most time with. Choose them carefully.

relationships_and_society.quote: What is rational is universal, and what is universal is rational.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: The principles of reason and virtue are common to all humanity, forming the basis for a universal ethics.

relationships_and_society.quote: How much more grievous are the consequences of anger than the causes of it.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: The harm your own anger does to your character and peace of mind is often worse than the initial offense.

relationships_and_society.quote: That which is not good for the bee-hive cannot be good for the bees.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: What harms the community ultimately harms the individual. Our well-being is interconnected.

relationships_and_society.quote: One of the most beautiful qualities of true friendship is to understand and to be understood.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: Mutual understanding and empathy, key components of interpersonal effectiveness, are at the heart of any meaningful friendship.

relationships_and_society.quote: The object of life is not to be on the side of the majority, but to escape finding oneself in the ranks of the insane.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: Prioritize truth and reason over popular opinion, which is often guided by cognitive biases and emotional contagion.

relationships_and_society.quote: Be careful to leave your sons well instructed rather than rich, for the hopes of the instructed are better than the wealth of the ignorant.
relationships_and_society.author: Epictetus
relationships_and_society.explanation: Passing on wisdom and virtue is a far greater inheritance than material wealth.

relationships_and_society.quote: When you are offended at any man's fault, turn to yourself and study your own failings. Then you will forget your anger.
relationships_and_society.author: Epictetus
relationships_and_society.explanation: Practicing self-awareness and humility is an effective antidote to anger at others' imperfections.

relationships_and_society.quote: Begin each day by telling yourself: Today I shall be meeting with interference, ingratitude, insolence... all of them due to the offenders’ ignorance of what is good or evil.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: Prepare yourself for others' faults not with cynicism, but with the understanding that they act from ignorance, not malice. This is a cognitive coping strategy.

relationships_and_society.quote: Wherever there is a human being, there is an opportunity for a kindness.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: Every interaction is a chance to practice the prosocial virtue of kindness.

relationships_and_society.quote: What is a friend? A single soul dwelling in two bodies.
relationships_and_society.author: Aristotle
relationships_and_society.explanation: True friendship is a profound connection based on shared virtue and mutual goodwill.

relationships_and_society.quote: The wise man is not he who knows many things, but he who knows useful things.
relationships_and_society.author: Aeschylus
relationships_and_society.explanation: The value of knowledge lies in its practical application to living a virtuous life and helping others.

relationships_and_society.quote: We are not born for ourselves alone.
relationships_and_society.author: Cicero
relationships_and_society.explanation: As social beings, we have a natural duty to our family, our community, and humanity as a whole.

relationships_and_society.quote: The way to love anything is to realize that it may be lost.
relationships_and_society.author: G.K. Chesterton
relationships_and_society.explanation: This literary insight mirrors the Stoic practice of negative visualization to cultivate gratitude for the people and things in our lives.

relationships_and_society.quote: No man is an island, entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent, a part of the main.
relationships_and_society.author: John Donne
relationships_and_society.explanation: A literary expression of the psychological truth of our interconnectedness. The well-being of the whole affects the individual.

relationships_and_society.quote: The only way to have a friend is to be one.
relationships_and_society.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
relationships_and_society.explanation: Friendship is not something you get, but something you create through your own virtuous and prosocial behaviors.

relationships_and_society.quote: If you want to lift yourself up, lift up someone else.
relationships_and_society.author: Booker T. Washington
relationships_and_society.explanation: Helping others (prosocial behavior) is one of the most effective ways to improve your own character and sense of well-being.

relationships_and_society.quote: We are members of one great body... We must consider that we are born for the good of the whole.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: Your primary duty is to the human community. Act in a way that benefits all of humanity (Hierocles's circles).

relationships_and_society.quote: A man's true greatness lies in the consciousness of an honest purpose in life.
relationships_and_society.author: Joseph Conrad
relationships_and_society.explanation: A good life in society is built on self-awareness and a virtuous, purposeful engagement with the world.

relationships_and_society.quote: The just man is not the one who does no injustice, but the one who, having the power, does not wish to do it.
relationships_and_society.author: Democritus
relationships_and_society.explanation: True virtue is not merely the absence of wrongdoing, but the conscious choice to act justly.

relationships_and_society.quote: Men exist for the sake of one another. Teach them then or bear with them.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: Your duty to others is twofold: to help them learn virtue (psychoeducation), or to patiently endure their ignorance (distress tolerance).

relationships_and_society.quote: A benefit consists not in what is done or given, but in the intention of the giver or doer.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: The virtue of an act of kindness lies in the will behind it, not in the material gift itself.

relationships_and_society.quote: He who has a why to live for can bear almost any how.
relationships_and_society.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
relationships_and_society.explanation: A strong sense of purpose (a 'why'), often found in service to others, provides the psychological resilience to endure any hardship.

relationships_and_society.quote: We are all leaves of a single tree, and the life of each is the life of all.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: Humanity is a single organism. The health of the whole depends on the health of each individual part.

relationships_and_society.quote: Whoever does wrong, wrongs himself.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: The primary victim of an unjust act is the person who commits it, for they have corrupted their own character.

relationships_and_society.quote: The first step in the acquisition of wisdom is silence, the second listening, the third memory, the fourth practice, the fifth teaching others.
relationships_and_society.author: Solomon ibn Gabirol
relationships_and_society.explanation: A medieval philosopher's step-by-step guide to skill acquisition, culminating in sharing wisdom for the benefit of the community.

relationships_and_society.quote: The reward for a good deed is to have done it.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: Virtuous action is intrinsically reinforcing. Do not look for external praise or compensation.

relationships_and_society.quote: Life is short—the fruit of this life is a good character and acts for the common good.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: The essence of a well-lived life is simple: cultivate a virtuous character and dedicate your actions to helping others.

relationships_and_society.quote: Humans have been born for the sake of other humans. So either teach them, or tolerate them.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: You have two primary duties in society: to educate others towards virtue, or to bear their failings with patience.

relationships_and_society.quote: A royal spirit is a man who can look things in the face, who is not frightened by the roar of the crowd.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: True leadership and virtue require the courage to stand by your principles, even when faced with social pressure.

relationships_and_society.quote: No one is more hated than he who speaks the truth.
relationships_and_society.author: Plato
relationships_and_society.explanation: Be prepared for social friction if you commit to living an honest, value-driven life. Not everyone wants to hear the truth.

relationships_and_society.quote: Interpersonal effectiveness skills are for achieving one's objectives in a way that maintains relationships and self-respect.
relationships_and_society.author: Marsha M. Linehan
relationships_and_society.explanation: The founder of DBT defines a core skill set: how to get what you want, keep relationships, and like yourself afterwards.

relationships_and_society.quote: He who is unable to live in society, or who has no need because he is sufficient for himself, must be either a beast or a god.
relationships_and_society.author: Aristotle
relationships_and_society.explanation: To be human is to be a social creature. Our nature as a species requires us to live and act within a community.

relationships_and_society.quote: If you would be a leader of men, you must lead your own mind.
relationships_and_society.author: Lao Tzu
relationships_and_society.explanation: This Eastern wisdom aligns with the Western principle that effective and virtuous influence in society begins with self-mastery.

relationships_and_society.quote: People will do anything, no matter how absurd, in order to avoid facing their own souls.
relationships_and_society.author: Carl Jung
relationships_and_society.explanation: A foundational insight of depth psychology: we often engage in distraction and avoidance to escape difficult self-reflection.

relationships_and_society.quote: He who has conferred a kindness should be silent; he who has received one should speak of it.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: Practice generosity without seeking recognition, and practice gratitude by acknowledging the help you receive.

relationships_and_society.quote: All that is mine I carry with me.
relationships_and_society.author: Bias of Priene
relationships_and_society.explanation: The only true possessions are your character and wisdom. These are the things you carry with you in all circumstances.

relationships_and_society.quote: Nothing is more honorable than a grateful heart.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: Gratitude is a cornerstone of a virtuous character and a peaceful, prosocial life.

relationships_and_society.quote: It is a characteristic of a wise man not to do what he has to do, but to do what he ought to do.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: Virtue often requires choosing the right, value-driven path, not just the necessary or easy one.

relationships_and_society.quote: A man's character is his guardian divinity.
relationships_and_society.author: Heraclitus
relationships_and_society.explanation: Your cultivated character is the ultimate force that protects and guides you through life.

relationships_and_society.quote: It is a mark of a good man to delight in good deeds.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: A virtuous person finds genuine joy in acting for the benefit of others, seeing it as a natural expression of their character.

relationships_and_society.quote: When you are silent, it is not a sign of weakness, but of strength.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: The discipline to hold your tongue, to listen, and to not react emotionally is a key strength in social interactions.

relationships_and_society.quote: The best answer to anger is silence.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: Responding to an angry person with silence refuses to fuel the fire and preserves your own tranquility.

relationships_and_society.quote: The greatest remedy for anger is delay.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: When you feel anger rising, create a space of time before you react. This allows reason to reassert itself over passion.

relationships_and_society.quote: Look for the good in people, not the bad.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: A virtuous mindset actively seeks to find the positive aspects of others, fostering a more compassionate and harmonious social life.

relationships_and_society.quote: A man should be upright, not be kept upright.
relationships_and_society.author: Marcus Aurelius
relationships_and_society.explanation: True virtue is internal. Your good character should come from your own principles, not from external pressure or the fear of being caught.

relationships_and_society.quote: It is a great man that can be both humble and great.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: The highest form of character combines personal excellence with a humble recognition of one's place in the larger community.

relationships_and_society.quote: The first duty of a man is to be true to himself.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: Before you can be of service to others, you must first live in accordance with your own rational nature and principles.

relationships_and_society.quote: A man who is a friend to himself is a friend to all.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: When you have cultivated inner peace and virtue, you are able to engage with all of society from a place of stability and goodwill.

relationships_and_society.quote: No one can live a happy life, or even a supportable life, without the study of wisdom.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: A commitment to philosophical practice is not a hobby, but an essential requirement for navigating life successfully.

relationships_and_society.quote: The good man is a friend to all, and an enemy to none.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: A person of virtue approaches everyone with goodwill, even those who act wrongly, seeing them as mistaken rather than as enemies.

relationships_and_society.quote: He who is good is happy.
relationships_and_society.author: Seneca
relationships_and_society.explanation: This is the core Stoic equation: happiness is not an external goal to be pursued, but the natural consequence of a virtuous character.

relationships_and_society.quote: The mind is the ruler of the soul.
relationships_and_society.author: Zeno of Citium
relationships_and_society.explanation: Your rational faculty is the governing part of your being; it must be trained to direct your impulses and choices.

relationships_and_society.quote: All things are parts of one single system, which is called Nature; the individual life is good when it is in harmony with Nature.
relationships_and_society.author: Zeno of Citium
relationships_and_society.explanation: The ultimate goal is to align your personal will and actions with the rational, cosmic order of the universe.

relationships_and_society.quote: Accepting reality is the only way to live a life that is not full of suffering.
relationships_and_society.author: Marsha M. Linehan
relationships_and_society.explanation: A direct quote on the power of radical acceptance from the creator of DBT, summarizing a principle that is also deeply Stoic.
